title: 107_hr1017
content: The "Anti-Spamming Act of 2001" is also known as the "Protection from Fraudulent Unsolicited E-mail." Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to include provisions regarding the transmission of bulk unsolicited electronic mail messages and the sale or distribution of computer programs designed to conceal the source of such messages. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, includes provisions related to the transmission of unsolicited electronic mail messages and the sale of programs designed to conceal message sources. The amendment specifies conditions under which such actions are prohibited and outlines offenses punishable under the section. The amendment to Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code prohibits the transmission of unsolicited electronic mail messages and the sale of programs designed to conceal message sources. It outlines offenses punishable under the section, including monetary loss and statutory damages for violations. The term 'Internet domain' refers to a specific computer system or collection of systems on the Internet with a registered domain name. 'Unsolicited electronic mail message' is defined as any identical message not initiated by the recipient. The term 'Internet' refers to the interconnected network of networks using TCP/IP to communicate information. Subsection (g) includes provisions for attorneys' fees and litigation costs. The term 'Internet' refers to the interconnected network of networks using TCP/IP to communicate information. Subsection (g) includes provisions for attorneys' fees and other litigation costs reasonably incurred in connection with the civil action after injunctive relief or other equitable relief.
